title: Wild elephants may have names that other elephants use to call them
excerpt: Research on the rumbles of wild elephants suggest that these animals address each other with unique, name-like vocalizations. (Story aired on All Things Considered on June 10, 2024.)

title: How First Contact With Whale Civilization Could Unfold
excerpt: If we can learn to speak their language, what should we say?

title: What Humans Can Learn From The Language Of Honeybees
excerpt: Advanced technologies like A.I. are enabling scientists to learn that the world is full of intelligent creatures with sophisticated languages, like honeybees. What might they tell us?

title: The Animal Translators
excerpt: Scientists are using machine learning to eavesdrop on naked mole rats, fruit bats, crows and whales — and to communicate back.

title: The Strange and Secret Ways That Animals Perceive the World
excerpt: Nonhuman creatures have senses that we’re just beginning to fathom. What would they tell us if we could only understand them?

title: Are We on the Verge of Chatting with Whales? | Hakai Magazine
excerpt: An ambitious project is attempting to interpret sperm whale clicks with artificial intelligence, then talk back to them.

title: The Elephant Ethogram
excerpt: Introduces the elephant ethogram: A Library of African Elephant Behavior

title: The First 'Google Translate' For Elephants Debuts
excerpt: An anonymous reader quotes a report from Scientific American: Elephants possess an incredibly rich repertoire of communication techniques, including hundreds of calls and gestures that convey specific meanings and can change depending on the context. title: The Story of One Whale Who Tried to Bridge the Linguistic Divide Between An
excerpt: While captive in a Navy program, a beluga whale named Noc began to mimic human speech. What was behind his attempt to talk to us?

title: The Challenges of Animal Translation
excerpt: Artificial intelligence may help us decode animalese. But how much will we really be able to understand?
